Simulation Study: 1 step regression GMWM vs 2 steps

simulation_study_gmwm_1_step_vs_2_step.Rmd

In this section, we study the performance of both estimators with a simulation study.

# libraries
library(simts)
library(gmwmx)
## Loading required package: stringi
## Loading required package: infuser
## Loading required package: wv
## 
## Attaching package: 'wv'
## The following object is masked from 'package:simts':
## 
##     unitConversion
## Loading required package: Matrix
## Loading required package: longmemo
## Loading required package: ltsa
## Loading required package: pbapply
## Loading required package: pbmcapply
## Loading required package: parallel
## Loading required package: rjson
## Loading required package: robustbase
## Registered S3 method overwritten by 'robustbase':
##   method    from 
##   print.lts simts
## Loading required package: MASS
## 
## Attaching package: 'MASS'
## The following object is masked from 'package:simts':
## 
##     select
## Loading required package: fs
# we consider example the model considered in model 3
phase =     0.45
amplitude = 2.5
sigma2_wn =       15
sigma2_powerlaw = 10
d =               0.4
bias =            0
trend =           5/365.25
cosU =            amplitude*cos(phase)
sinU =            amplitude*sin(phase)


# consider 500 observations
n = 7.5 * 365
model_i = WN(sigma2 = sigma2_wn) + PLP(sigma2 = sigma2_powerlaw, d = d) 

# generate data
# define time at which there are jumps
jump_vec =  c(600, 1200, 2000)
jump_height = c(10, 15, 20)


# define number of parameter estimated (depends on the model)
nbr_param = 2 + length(jump_vec)+ 2 + 3
library(doParallel)
library(progress)
library(foreach)
# generate residuals
# define myseed
myseed=123
eps = simts::gen_gts(model = model_i, n= n)

# add trend, gaps and sin
X = flicker::create_X_matrix(1:length(eps), jump_vec, n_seasonal =  1)

# define beta
beta = c(bias, trend,  cosU,  sinU, jump_height)

# create time series
yy = simts::gen_mean(X, beta) + eps

gnssts_obj = create.gnssts(t = 1:length(yy), y = yy, jumps = jump_vec)


# estimate gmwm 1 step
estimate_gmwm_1_step = flicker::run_one_gmwm_twosteps_base(x = gnssts_obj,
                                                           model = "wn+powerlaw", theta_0 = c(0.1,0.1,0.1),
                                                           n_seasonal = 1, robust = F, ci = T, k_iter = 1)


# estimate gmwm 2 step
estimate_gmwm_2_steps = flicker::run_one_gmwm_twosteps_base(x = gnssts_obj,
                                                    model = "wn+powerlaw", theta_0 = c(0.1,0.1,0.1),
                                                    n_seasonal = 1, robust = F, ci = T, k_iter = 2)




################
# Simulation study comparing the GMWM 1 step vs GMWM 2 steps
###############


# define number of monte carlo simulation
B = 100



# define matrix
results_simulation_gmwm_1_vs_2_steps = array(data = NA, dim=c(B, nbr_param*2, 2) )
dimnames(results_simulation_gmwm_1_vs_2_steps)[[3]] <- c("GMWM 1 step", "GMWM 2 step")

# progress bar
pb <- progress_bar$new(total = B)
tictoc::tic()

for(b in seq(B)){

  # fix seed for reproducibility
  set.seed(myseed + b)
  
  # generate residuals
  eps = simts::gen_gts(model = model_i, n= n)
  
  # add trend, gaps and sin
  X = flicker::create_X_matrix(t_nogap = 1:length(eps), jumps = jump_vec, n_seasonal  =  1)
  
  # create time series
  yy = simts::gen_mean(X, beta) + eps
  
  # save signal in temp
  gnssts_obj = create.gnssts(t = 1:length(yy), y = yy, jumps = jump_vec)

  fit_simu_b_gmwm_1_step = flicker::run_one_gmwm_twosteps_base(x = gnssts_obj,
                                                      
                                                             model = "wn+powerlaw", theta_0 = c(0.1,0.1,0.1),
                                                             n_seasonal = 1,  robust = F, ci = T, k_iter = 1)
  
  fit_simu_b_gmwm_2_step = flicker::run_one_gmwm_twosteps_base(x = gnssts_obj,
                                                               
                                                               model = "wn+powerlaw", theta_0 = c(0.1,0.1,0.1),
                                                               n_seasonal = 1,  robust = F, ci = T, k_iter = 2)
  
  # save in matrix
  fit_gmwm_1_step =  c(fit_simu_b_gmwm_1_step$beta_hat, fit_simu_b_gmwm_1_step$theta_hat)
  fit_gmwm_2_step =  c(fit_simu_b_gmwm_2_step$beta_hat, fit_simu_b_gmwm_2_step$theta_hat)
  
  # save in array of results
  results_simulation_gmwm_1_vs_2_steps[b,, 1 ] = fit_gmwm_1_step
  results_simulation_gmwm_1_vs_2_steps[b,, 2 ] = fit_gmwm_2_step
  pb$tick()

  
}


save(results_simulation_gmwm_1_vs_2_steps, file="data/results_simulation_gmwm_1_vs_2_steps.rda")
data("results_simulation_gmwm_1_vs_2_steps", package="gmwmx")
# plot results
# define vector of parameters to be estimated
theta_vec = c(bias, trend,  cosU, sinU, jump_height, sigma2_wn, sigma2_powerlaw, d)
names(theta_vec) = c("bias", "trend",   "cosU", "sinU",rep("jump_height", length(jump_vec)) , "sigma2_wn", "sigma2_powerlaw", "d")
theta_vec

par(mfrow=c(2,4))
for(i in seq(nbr_param-3)){
  boxplot(results_simulation_gmwm_1_vs_2_steps[,i,1],
          results_simulation_gmwm_1_vs_2_steps[,i,2], 
          main =  names(theta_vec)[i], names=c("1 step", "2 steps"))
  abline(h=theta_vec[i], col="blue4")
}

par(mfrow=c(2,2))
for(i in 8:10){
  boxplot(results_simulation_gmwm_1_vs_2_steps[,i,1],
          results_simulation_gmwm_1_vs_2_steps[,i,2], 
          main =  names(theta_vec)[i], names=c("1 step", "2 steps"))
  abline(h=theta_vec[i], col="blue4")
}
